subj-group.subject: Critical Reviews in Oral Biology & Medicine

title-group.subtitle: Directions and Perspectives in Oral Regenerative Medicine

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Morphology, Biological Sciences Institute, Federal University of Minas Gerais, Av. Antônio Carlos, 6627- 31.270-901, Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil
2Dental School, Federal University of Minas Gerais, Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil
3Department of Biochemistry and Immunology, Biological Sciences Institute, Federal University of Minas Gerais, Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil

abstract.p: One of the main goals of bone tissue engineering is to identify and develop new biomaterials and scaffolds for structural support and controlled cell growth, which allow for formation or replacement of bone tissue. Recently, carbon nanotubes (CNT) have emerged as a potential candidate for bone tissue engineering. CNT present remarkable mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties with easy functionalization capability and biocompatibility. In oral regenerative medicine, bone reconstruction is an essential requirement for functional rehabilitation of the stomatognathic system. Autologous bone still represents the gold standard graft material for bone reconstruction. However, the small amounts of bone available in donor regions, together with the high costs of surgeries, are critical aspects that hinder the selection of this procedure. Thus, CNT alone or combined with biopolymers have promise to be used as novel potential biomaterials for the restoration of bone defects. Indeed, recent evidence demonstrates CNT to be a feasible material that can increase the formation of bone in tooth sockets of rats. The purpose of this review is to summarize the recent developments in bone repair/regeneration with CNT or CNT-based composites. We further provide an overview of bone tissue engineering and current applications of biomaterials, especially of CNT, to enhance bone regeneration.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Tissue engineering is a multidisciplinary field focused on the development of new applications for the regeneration of lost tissues and for the restoration of function in damaged human tissues and organs, using expertise in chemistry, physics, engineering, and the life and clinical sciences (Langer and Vacanti, 1993). For tissue regeneration to be achieved, 3 major elements must be combined: scaffolds or membranes, regenerative or stem cells, and cell-signaling molecules or growth factors (Bottino et al., 2012). Moreover, tissue engineering aims to restore tissue function by growing cells on a designed scaffold that creates a three-dimensional (3D) microenvironment for cell support (Gupte and Ma, 2012). An ideal scaffold should mimic the natural extracellular matrix environment, providing the necessary framework for nutrients, oxygen, and metabolic waste transport for the cells (Li et al., 2005).

In this context, since the bone is the second most frequently transplanted human tissue (Kotela et al., 2009), there is tremendous interest in the development of novel strategies to assist repair or replace bone defects. Thus, bone tissue engineering must overcome the drawbacks of current clinical allografting and autografting treatment methods and create new strategies to heal bone loss due to trauma, bone tumor resection, or musculoskeletal and periodontal diseases (Bhattacharyya et al., 2008; Sitharaman et al., 2008; Tutak et al., 2009). Several materials have been proposed that can be used adjacent to the bone, such as titanium, cobalt chromium, stainless steel, alumina ceramics, zirconia ceramics, hydroxyapatite ceramics, and, more recently, synthetic polymers (Katti, 2004). However, materials made from metal often suffer wear and cannot take on the stress-shielding effect when incorporated into the human body. The stress-shielding effect results from a large difference in the Young’s modulus between metal and human bone. Consequently, bone is insufficiently loaded compared with metallic implants, thereby causing a reduction in bone density (Uhthoff and Finnegan, 1983; Liao et al., 2012). Additionally, bioceramics have been used for bone regeneration because of their biocompatibility. Nevertheless, their clinical application is limited because of their inherent brittleness, difficulty in being shaped, and an extremely slow degradation/resorption rate (Porter et al., 2009). In contrast, synthetic polymers are gaining popularity because they can be designed to achieve high processing capacity, biocompatibility, and biodegradability; however, these materials are deficient in the compressive modulus compared with native bone tissue (Porter et al., 2009; Bottino et al., 2012). Thus, currently, no biomaterial has all of the characteristics of an ideal material, particularly with regard to a porous 3D structure to allow for osteoconduction and bone ingrowth (Sitharaman et al., 2008). With an aim to reduce or eliminate these limitations, several high-modulus micro- and/or nano-scale inorganic constituents have been utilized to improve the physical and biological performance of synthetic bone scaffolds. These materials include carbon nanotubes (CNT) and ceramic or metal micro- and nanofibers/spheres (Weiss et al., 2007; Porter et al., 2009; Lee et al., 2011).

The nature of the nano-dimensionality has logically given rise to an interest in using nanomaterials for bone tissue engineering applications (Harrison and Atala, 2007). In the past few years, CNT have emerged as a potential biomaterial in bone tissue engineering due to their remarkable mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties, and easy functionalization capability and biocompatibility (Iijima, 1991; Irineu et al., 2012; Liao et al., 2012; Cheng et al., 2013). These characteristics have motivated many investigators to address their applicability in medicine; however, several questions about their biocompatibility, toxicity, and the mechanisms of action that lead to bone formation are controversial and still remain unanswered.

Thus, the purpose of this review is to highlight the recent developments in bone repair/regeneration using CNT or CNT-based composites, namely, CNT associated with different molecules or materials. Specifically, we will provide an overview of bone tissue engineering and the current usage of various biomaterials to enhance bone formation, focusing on the potential actions of CNT in bone formation and repair/regeneration.

sec.title: Synthesis, Characterization, and Properties of Carbon Nanotubes
sec.p: CNT are well-ordered hollow nanostructures consisting of carbon atoms bonded to each other via sp2 bonds, which are stronger than sp and sp3 bonds (Tran et al., 2009). The architectural structure of CNT makes them mechanically stronger, electrically and thermally more conductive, and chemically and biologically more active than graphite. The density of CNT is similar to that of graphite, which, in turn, is much lower than that of any other metal bone-scaffolding materials, including steel and titanium (Zanello et al., 2006). The most widely used method of synthesizing CNT is chemical vapor deposition (Cassell et al., 1999). This process typically involves reacting a metal catalyst with a hydrocarbon feedstock at high temperatures (> 700°C). Depending on the reaction conditions, one can create a wide variety of lengths (nanometers to millimeters) and widths (1-100 nm) of CNT (Harrison and Atala, 2007).

Theoretically, CNT can be visualized as a rolled-up graphene sheet with a relatively large length-to-diameter ratio aspect that may exceed 106. One such sheet will form a single-walled CNT (SWCNT), while more than one concentric graphene sheet creates a multi-walled CNT (MWCNT). SWCNT have diameters ranging typically from 0.5 to 1.5 nm and lengths ranging from 100 nm to several micrometers, whereas MWCNT have larger diameters (more than 100 nm), due to their multilayered structure, and the distance between 2 layers is approximately 0.34 nm (Tran et al., 2009) (Fig. 1). The diameters of CNT are close to the size of triple helix collagen fibers. This makes CNT an ideal candidate material to be used as a substrate to promote bone growth (Zanello et al., 2006).

caption.p: Schematic representation of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT). SWCNT is formed by only one rolled-up graphene sheet, while MWCNT is composed of more than one rolled-up concentric graphene sheet. SWCNT have diameters ranging from 0.5 to 1.5 nm and lengths ranging from 100 nm up to several micrometers, whereas MWCNT have larger diameters (more than 100 nm) and lengths ranging from 0.1 to 50 µm. Adapted from Zarbin (2007).

sec.p: The extraordinary mechanical properties of CNT, such as high tensile strength and excellent flexibility, come from the bonds between the carbon atoms, in addition to their metallic character and high thermal and electrical conductivity. The elastic responses of CNT to deformation and flexibility are also outstanding (Wong et al., 1997; Riaz et al., 2009; Tonelli et al., 2012). Experimental measurements together with theoretical calculations show that CNT exhibit the highest Young’s modulus and tensile strength among known materials (Overney et al., 1993). The high degree of flexibility is directly related to the cohesion of the solid and, therefore, the covalent chemical bonding of carbon atoms therein (Tonelli et al., 2012).

Analysis of both theoretical and experimental data shows that CNT can sustain up to 15% of tensile strain before fracture, and their implantation into bone may improve the mechanical properties of damaged bone tissue (Zanello et al., 2006). From this viewpoint, CNT may not only be used to stimulate bone regeneration but also may serve a permanent mechanical role (Zanello et al., 2006). Moreover, the small radius, large specific-surface area, and rehybridization capability make CNT very attractive for many applications because of their strong sensitivity to chemical and environmental interactions (Meyyappan, 2005). In contrast, the absence of dangling bonds confers chemical inertness for their use in biological applications. The chemical inertia of CNT can hinder their interaction with other materials, such as polymers. The major reason for this inertia is the low dispersion of CNT in water or organic solvents. Recent progress in the chemistry of CNT functionalization, i.e., their chemical association with different molecules, has allowed this limitation to be circumvented (Bhattacharyya et al., 2008).

The functionalization process of CNT can improve their solubility, processability, and biocompatibility. Moreover, it allows for the combination of the exceptional properties of CNT with those of other types of materials. Several methods for the functionalization of CNT have been developed, including covalent functionalization of sidewalls, non-covalent exohedral functionalization, endohedral functionalization, and defect functionalization. The process of functionalization involves the selective breaking of C=C bonds in CNT, resulting in carboxyl groups. These groups can then be used as subsidiary sites for additional reactions, thereby improving their biocompatibility. Overall, functionalization schemes depend on the presence of defects (both neutral and charged) along the CNT structure, which determines the supporting reactions (Hu et al., 2009; Lin et al., 2011). Therefore, the functionalization process allows for the association of CNT with several compounds, thus creating the possibility of combining the CNT properties with specific characteristics of different materials. CNT-based composites have been developed to meet the mechanical properties of bone, specifically the elasticity modulus (Bhattacharyya et al., 2011). For instance, Bhattacharyya et al. (2008) utilized CNT to improve the mechanical properties of hydrogels based on hyaluronic acid (HY) without altering its ability to absorb water. Indeed, analysis of the viscoelastic properties of the material showed that HY-CNT gels had a stronger and more rigid structure than HY native gels, thereby indicating that the functionalization of CNT with HY produced a reinforced gel with greater stability (Bhattacharyya et al., 2008).

sec.title: Bone Tissue: Architecture and Regenerative Treatments
sec.p: The bone tissue has a hierarchical organization over length scales that comprise several orders of magnitude from the macro-scale (centimeter) to the nanostructured (extracellular matrix) components (Stevens, 2008) (Fig. 2). This 3D architecture permits the interaction of large quantities of molecules, especially proteins, and cells that further interact in synergy to create a complex microenvironment (Mattioli-Belmonte et al., 2012).

caption.p: Hierarchical organization of bone over different length scales. Bone has a strong calcified outer compact layer (a), comprised of many cylindrical Haversian systems, or osteons (b). The resident cells are coated in a forest of cell membrane receptors that respond to specific binding sites (c) and the well-defined nanoarchitecture of the surrounding extracellular matrix (d). [Reproduced with permission from Stevens (2008).]

sec.p: Because of its high regenerative capacity, bone is able to recover from fractures without the need for major interventions (Stevens, 2008). However, large bone defects lack the template for an orchestrated regeneration and often require surgical intervention (Stevens, 2008; Cheng et al., 2013), thereby representing a hard-to-solve problem and a major challenge for physicians and dentists.

During the past several years, surgeons have had to deal with limited options (autologous or allogeneic bone) to treat patients suffering from large bone defects. Autografts are restricted by the shortage of supply and reduced mechanical stability and may provoke morbidity in the donor area (Finkemeier, 2002). In addition, there is often need for a second surgery, which is contraindicated for older patients and those suffering from systemic diseases. Conversely, the use of allografts is even more limited because of the risk of immune responses and disease transmission (Silber et al., 2003; Cheng et al., 2013). Furthermore, long-term storage of allografts can cause damage to the bone structure and death of osteoprogenitor cells (Cheng et al., 2013). For these reasons, animal xenografts and synthetic alloplasts, such as hydroxyapatite (HA), polymers, and bioactive glass, have been introduced as alternatives to bone replacement grafts (Kao and Scott, 2007). The outcome of the bone tissue regenerative process at grafted sites depends on 3 fundamental factors: (i) the osteoconductive matrix, which allows for vascular invasion and cellular infiltration; (ii) osteoinductive factors, which recruit and induce mesenchymal cells to differentiate into mature bone-forming cells; and (iii) osteogenic cells capable of laying new bone matrix (Miron and Zhang, 2012).

Since, nanotechnology allows for the development of new systems that mimic the complex and hierarchical structure of native tissues (Armentano et al., 2010), it represents a new frontier in bone tissue engineering (Armentano et al., 2010). Thus, advances in the knowledge and technology of bone tissue engineering and of the CNT chemistry may allow for the development of CNT-based scaffolds that can overcome the limitations of current treatment options for large bone defects. In bone tissue, it is believed that CNT may function like collagen fibers during the deposition of bone matrix, controlling events of crystal nucleation and growth of the inorganic component (Zhao et al., 2005). Ongoing studies have shown that CNT sustain the growth of osteoblasts and bone formation (Tutak et al., 2009). Also, Narita et al. (2009) have reported that MWCNT inhibit osteoclastic bone resorption in vivo, suggesting that they have beneficial effects on the bone. Since CNT are not biodegradable, they behave like an inert matrix in which cells can proliferate and deposit new living material, thus becoming functional bone (Sahithi et al., 2010).

sec.title: Recent Knowledge of Carbon-nanotube-based Scaffolds
sec.p: Because of the relative novelty of the tissue-engineering field, several materials and compositions have been tested as scaffolds for bone tissue repair/regeneration (Zaky and Cancedda, 2009). It is accepted that the ideal scaffold should have stability, biocompatibility, biopermeability, pore size between 100 μm and 500 μm, and high pore interconnectivity through which nutrients can diffuse and cells can migrate and proliferate and should also promote bone tissue ingrowth (Serrano et al., 2007; Sitharaman et al., 2008; Mendes et al., 2010; Sahithi et al., 2010; Cheng et al., 2013). Micropores are important because they allow both vascular formation and waste transport, which are crucial for cell survival inside the scaffold (Sahithi et al., 2010).

To overcome the negative issues related to metallic materials, such as wear and the stress-shielding effect, CNT, due to their large aspect ratio, extraordinarily high Young’s modulus, superior flexibility, and excellent electrical conductivity, have been widely used as reinforcing fillers for polymers to form nanocomposites with functional properties (Liao et al., 2012). In this context, it has been reported that the development of several CNT-based composites can act as scaffolds to enhance bone tissue repair/regeneration (Table). Analysis of the preponderance of the data suggests that the use of CNT improves biocompatibility, mechanical properties of the scaffolds, cell differentiation and proliferation, and bone tissue deposition. More importantly, these studies provide insights into the CNT mechanisms and interactions with cells that permit the acceleration and/or augmentation of bone tissue formation.

caption.p: Compilation of Recent Studies with Carbon Nanotubes (CNT) for Bone-tissue-engineering Purposes

tr.td: f-MWCNT-g-chitosan/Hap scaffold
Good thermal stability, interconnected porosity, controlled degradation, and cell proliferation
MWCNT-coated 3D collagen sponge
Favorable biocompatibility, osteoblast differentiation, and promotion of bone-tissue formation
PLGA/c-MWCNT nanocomposite
Good mechanical properties, promotion of cell growth, and induced MSCs to differentiate into osteoblasts
Mattioli-Belmonte et al., 2011
MWCNT-PCL composite
MWCNT-PCL nanocomposites were able to sustain osteoblast proliferation and modulate cell morphology
MWCNT/PCL composite
MWCNT/PCL composites promoted proliferation and differentiation of BMSCs
PVAl hydrogel alone or reinforced with 2 types of carbon nanoparticles
No interference in cell viability, metabolic activity, morphology, and spreading of the cell types analyzed; induction of osteogenic differentiation
HA/VAMWCNT nanocomposite
Excellent bioactivity and induction of biomineralization with biological apatite deposition
PP/MWNT-nHA nanocomposite
Enhanced biocompatibility, stiffness, tensile strength, and impact toughness
MWCNT/HA composite
Good mechanical properties, biocompatibility, and osseointegration
CNT/PLGA scaffold
Higher mechanical strength, induction of cell attachment, and proliferation and differentiation

fn.p: Abbreviations: HA = hydroxyapatite; MWCNT = multi-walled carbon nanotubes; PCL = polycaprolactone; BMSCs = rat bone-marrow-derived stroma cells; PLGA = poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid); MSCs = rat bone-marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells; HA/VAMWCNT = biomineralized nanohydroxyapatite/vertically aligned multi-walled carbon nanotube; PVAl = polyvinyl alcohol; PP/MWNT-nHA = polypropylene biocomposites reinforced with carbon nanotubes and hydroxyapatite nanorods.

sec.p: For example, Liao et al. (2012) proposed a polypropylene biocomposite reinforced with MWCNT and HA nanorods (PP/MWNT-nHA) to be used as a bone replacement. Incorporation of MWCNT was beneficial in enhancing the stiffness, tensile strength, and impact toughness of the nanocomposite, apart from increasing the number of osteoblasts. Those authors explained that these carbonaceous fillers of nanometric dimensions served as an effective seeding site for osteoblasts. Also, they discussed that the exceptional topography of the CNT surfaces provided an enhanced osteoblastic adhesion, resulting in the selective absorption and attachment of proteins from the cell culture medium by means of C-C bonds. Regarding the surface chemistry, proteins adsorb and adhere to hydrophobic CNT surfaces readily because of their graphitic structure and small diameter, with a high surface energy and area (Grinnell and Feld, 1982).

Moreover, studies utilizing MWCNT/polycaprolactone (PCL) composite scaffolds (Mattioli-Belmonte et al., 2012; Pan et al., 2012) and biodegradable poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA)/carboxyl-functionalized MWCNT nanocomposites (Lin et al., 2011) argued in favor of the importance of the architecture and morphology of the CNT in a substrate/scaffold for promoting cell growth and proliferation. Particularly, Lin et al. (2011) demonstrated that the improved ability of cells to attach in higher numbers to PLGA/c-MWCNTS films was because of increased protein absorption and decreased contact angles. Also, these authors found a higher osteoblastic differentiation on PLGA/c-MWCNTS films and suggested that MWCNT induced cell differentiation in osteogenic cells by the adsorption of more proteins to the scaffold.

Additionally, using a porous scaffold composed of CNT and PLGA, Cheng et al. (2013) reported that CNT/PLGA composite scaffolds possessed increased mechanical strength. Furthermore, incorporation of CNT into PLGA led to the proliferation of osteoblasts and a higher rate of differentiation when compared with those of the control PLGA group. These results could be attributed to higher surface roughness and stiffness, as well as the excess bonding of growth factors to CNT. The incorporation of CNT also provided an opportunity to regulate phenotypic expression and lineage specification of stem cells by electrical cues (Cheng et al., 2013).

Although these studies showed promising results, caution is extremely necessary, since many questions are still unanswered and the mechanisms of action of these biocomposites are still largely unknown. Do CNT-based scaffolds influence types of cells other than osteoblasts and osteoclasts? Is the inflammatory response modulated by CNT to permit their beneficial effects on bone repair/regeneration? Do CNT cause toxicological effects? These and other points must be clarified before CNT can become a routinely used material in bone regenerative medicine.

sec.title: Application of Carbon Nanotubes in Oral Regenerative Medicine
sec.p: There is no doubt that dentistry is one of the branches of medicine most interested in the application of new knowledge acquired from the recent advances in tissue engineering and, particularly, in the field of nanotechnology. Important areas such as implantology, periodontics, and oral and maxillofacial surgery can benefit tremendously from the development of new nanomaterials (Fig. 3).

caption.p: Diagram showing a variety of applications of nanotechnology in oral regenerative medicine.

sec.p: In the past few years, CNT combined with biopolymers have been novel potential biomaterials that may aid in the restoration of bone defects in dentistry. Currently, much information about the synthesis, characterization, and properties of CNT is available; however, more in vitro and in vivo studies are needed for a better comprehension of their effects on bone repair/regeneration. In 2010, Mendes et al. evaluated the effects of SWCNT associated with sodium hyaluronate (HY-SWCNT) on bone repair/ regeneration of tooth sockets in rats. Treatment of sockets with this nanomaterial increased the formation of bone trabeculae approximately 3-fold and decreased the number of cell nuclei, thus indicating that the healing process was advanced in comparison with that in control sockets. Also, the expression of type I collagen was increased by ~46% in treated sockets after 7 days of tooth extraction. This is an important finding, since, during the bone healing process, the collagen fibrils form osteoid, which allows for the deposition of crystals of carbonated hydroxyapatite responsible for mineralization of the bone matrix (Bouletreau et al., 2002). Thus, an augmented expression of collagen type I in HY-SWCNT-treated sockets further suggests that the healing process is accelerated in these sockets (Mendes et al., 2010). No evidence of toxicity was observed in this study (Mendes et al., 2010) (Fig. 4).

caption.p: Effects of carbon nanotubes functionalized with sodium hyaluronate (HY-CNT) on tooth socket repair. (top panel) Schematic representation. (A) Fresh socket after tooth extraction, showing reminiscent periodontal ligament (PDL) containing osteoprogenitor cells. (B) Tooth socket immediately after HY-CNT administration and formation of blood clot.(C) HY-CNT interacting with cells inside tooth socket. (C1)Possible interaction between HY-CNT and host cells intermediated by CD44 and/or RHAMM receptor. (C2) After the interaction between HY-CNT and osteoprogenitor cells, the biomaterial might induce migration, proliferation, and differentiation of these cells into osteoblasts. (D) Incorporation of osteoblast cells into the HY-CNT 3D structure. The biomaterial acts as a scaffold supporting osteoblast cells, which deposit bone matrix inside the tooth socket. (E) Complete tooth socket healing process. The illustrations do not reflect the real size of the structures. (bottom panel) Representative photomicrographs of histological sections of sockets 7 days after tooth extraction. (F) Carbopol-treated sockets (control − 40x magnification); (G) HY-CNT 100 μg/mL-treated sockets (40x magnification); and (H) HY-CNT 100 μg/mL-treated sockets (400x magnification). Sockets treated with HY-CNT presented increased trabecular bone formation when compared with control sockets (arrows). B, basal bone; S, bone septum.

sec.p: Similar methodology was used to investigate the effects of HY-SWCNT on bone repair/regeneration of tooth sockets of rats under conditions in which bone repair/regeneration was hindered. It is well-known that diabetes alters bone metabolism by reducing both neoformation and resorption, prolonging the process of bone tissue repair/regeneration. Thus, the effects of HY-SWCNT were tested in rats with type I diabetes, induced by streptozotocin (Sá et al., 2013). It was found that, 14 days after tooth extraction, the bone repair/regeneration was approximately 3.3-fold higher in tooth sockets of diabetic rats treated with the nanomaterial. The treatment markedly increased the formation of bone trabeculae and reduced the number of cell nuclei, reaching values similar to those observed in non-diabetic rats. Therefore, the treatment with HY-SWCNT was able to restore the bone repair/regeneration process in tooth sockets of diabetic rats (Sá et al., 2013).

In summary, both of the above-described studies (Mendes et al., 2010; Sá et al., 2013) verified that HY-SWCNT have great potential use for bone regenerative procedures in dentistry, in normal and adverse metabolic states. Corroborating these findings, Usui et al. (2008) conducted a series of experiments implanting MWCNT into different types of bone in mice. First, they implanted MWCNT subperiosteally into the skull to evaluate bone-tissue compatibility. At 1 and 4 wks post-surgery, there were no significant signs of incompatibility. These authors then implanted MWCNT into tibial defects to examine their influence on bone healing during 4 wks and found a bone formation pattern similar to that of the control group, suggesting that the nanomaterial did not inhibit bone regeneration. More importantly, MWCNT particles promoted immediate HA crystallization on their surfaces, acting as a core for initial HA crystallization.

sec.title: Perspectives of Nanotechnology in Oral Regenerative Medicine
sec.p: Alveolar bone is an essential structure that plays a key role in tooth support, dental implant osseointegration, and denture stability (Zaky and Cancedda, 2009; Hsu and Wang, 2013). After tooth extraction, bone is resorbed in a progressive and irreversible manner, resulting in dimensional changes in the edentulous area (Bodic et al., 2005). CNT arise as a new biomaterial to be used in oral regenerative medicine, with the potential capacity to support periodontal and implant regenerative procedures.

In periodontics, when there is a considerable loss of attachment level caused by periodontal disease, regenerative therapies are essential. Guided tissue regeneration (GTR) is a widely used procedure which combines bone grafting to a membrane barrier to correct periodontal defects (Hsu and Wang, 2013). GTR is also useful for restoration of deficient alveolar sites, and, in these cases, it is referred to as guided bone regeneration (GBR). The majority of resorbable synthetic polymer membranes for periodontal/bone regeneration commercially available are based on polyesters or tissue-derived collagens (Bottino et al., 2012). Both types represent many structural, mechanical, and functional limitations. Bottino et al. (2012) reported that the next generation of membranes for tissue engineering should be biologically active, spatially designed, and functionally graded nanofibrous materials that closely mimic the native extracellular matrix. Thus, considering the results obtained with the use of HY-SWCNT on bone repair/regeneration of tooth sockets of rats (Mendes et al., 2010; Sá et al., 2013), utilization of this nanomaterial in GTR might promote favorable outcomes in terms of clinical attachment gain. Furthermore, their unique porous 3D structure applied to reconstructive periodontal technology would create a more predicable environment for the integration of different tissues (gingival, cementum, alveolar bone, and periodontal connective tissue) and cell proliferation. A recent study reported that the adjunctive application of HY after scaling and root planing may have positive effects on probing depth reduction and may prevent recolonization by periodontopathogens (Eick et al., 2013). Thus, considering the low stability of HY, its functionalization with CNT can lead to better results, since this procedure increases the stability of the HY, especially in aqueous environments such as the mouth (Mendes et al., 2008).

From the implantology point of view, the use of nanocomposites in regenerative therapies is promising. The application of CNT, alone or in combination with other biomaterials, in fresh tooth sockets would allow for better alveolar ridge preservation. The tooth socket could be covered by a membrane to keep the biomaterial for a longer period inside the tooth sockets. Moreover, in deficient edentulous ridges where surgical augmentation procedures are frequently needed to enhance post-extraction sites, maxillary implants often require sinus elevation procedures. Autogenous bone grafts, despite being the best choice in these cases, may not always be performed due to the unavailability of bone donor sites. Furthermore, extensive graft resorption has been reported in patients treated with allografts (Spin-Neto et al., 2013). Also, CNT may be used, alone or in combination with other polymers, in receptor sites of dental implants to accelerate the osseointegration process, thereby reducing the post-operative period until the patients’ oral rehabilitation is complete. Thus, tissue engineering with CNT alone or associated with other biomaterials may represent an optimal regenerative option in implantology.

Although CNT have been extensively characterized, presenting many potential applications in a variety of biological areas, there is no definitive inference about their toxicity (Fiorito et al., 2006). However, the number of studies suggesting that CNT are non-toxic in vivo is greater than those proposing the opposite (Firme et al., 2010). The reason for this controversy is due to the experimental model used, the characteristics of CNT (length, type of functionalization, concentration, duration of the exposure, and dispersant used for solubilization), and the tested parameters (Clichici et al., 2012). Overall, while some points of view have been reconciled, many aspects of CNT toxicity remain uncertain (Firme et al., 2010). In this regard, it is important to note that the amount of CNT used in dental applications is supposed to be very low, which reduces the possibility of inducing toxicological effects in patients. Additionally, the bone tissue is not a highly vascularized tissue when compared with other tissues, such as the liver. This characteristic diminishes the translocation of CNT to the bloodstream. Thus, it is believed that CNT remain in the bone tissue, minimizing systemic responses. However, further studies should be conducted to evaluate the systemic distribution and toxicity of CNT when used in dentistry (Fig. 5).

caption.p: Diagram depicts possible distribution of carbon nanotubes (CNT) in different organs and tissues after their introduction into the bone. Since the toxicological effects of CNT are still controversial, careful investigations should be conducted.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Bone tissue engineering is an exciting interdisciplinary field wherein developments can directly affect the field of dentistry by the generation of innovative materials and novel approaches. As demonstrated by many studies, CNT is among the unique biomaterials that hold potential applications in oral regenerative medicine, with their impressive capacity of accelerating bone repair/regeneration. Nevertheless, the challenge remains to establish the safety of CNT for human use, before being translated into clinical applications for bone repair/regeneration.

The authors declare no potential conflicts of interest with respect to authorship and/or publication of this article.
